comment_text: How do you get them Back?

They used us Dockyard apprentices to watch the avgas lines for leaks when they tested the catapults on the old HMAS Melbourne like this.

No they aren’t supposed to sink. They are sealed so they float. It was my job on the tugs to recover, tow back to the floating crane for lifting back onto the flight deck to have them shot off again.

The reason I always hated this show was because it would pose a question and then not answer it...

"The sled gets damaged when it bounces, we want it to sink, we don't want it to bounce."
"Why did it bounce? Here's some science to explain it."
proceeds to explain why any object would bounce, or skip, but not what was wrong with the sled that was just supposed to sink

Here’s my theory:
Water is incompressible. Build up enough speed and water will resist an incoming force. Since water is incompressible a fast moving object with a large, flat surface area will have its forward momentum redirected back upwards. It’s the same principle as skipping stones.
